title: GE CARESCAPE Canvas Monitor – Power Issue
description: Structured Clinical Engineering guide for a GE CARESCAPE Canvas monitor that will not power on.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: If the monitor is in clinical use: Transfer the patient to a functioning monitor first. Do not troubleshoot while the monitor is actively required for patient care. Confirm the device is safe to remove from service before proceeding.

steps.title: Verify AC Power at the Outlet
steps.instructions: Confirm the monitor is connected to a known-working hospital-grade outlet. Test the outlet with a known-good device (lamp, outlet tester, etc.). If plugged into a power strip, isolation transformer, or UPS, verify that device is powered on and functioning. If available, try a different known-working wall outlet. Why this matters: Loss of upstream power is the most common and simplest cause of a “dead” monitor.

steps.title: Inspect and Reseat the Power Cord
steps.instructions: Visually inspect the power cord for cuts or fraying, bent or damaged prongs, and loose connector ends. Reseat the cord firmly at the wall outlet and the rear AC inlet of the monitor. If available, swap with a known-good hospital-grade power cord and attempt to power on again. Why this matters: A loose or internally failed cord can mimic total device failure.

steps.title: Confirm the Rear Power Switch Position
steps.instructions: Verify the rear power rocker switch is in the ON position. Then press the front power button. Do not assume the switch position without physically checking it.

steps.title: Observe for Any Signs of Activity
steps.instructions: When attempting to power on, closely observe front LED indicators, brief screen flash, audible fan noise, or clicking sounds. Even minimal activity suggests partial power presence and helps narrow down whether the failure is complete or localized.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: If the monitor shows no indicator lights, no fan noise, no display activity, and no response with known-good outlet and power cord, then common external causes have been ruled out. At this point, the issue is likely internal (power supply board, internal fuse, or power distribution failure). Remove the monitor from service, label clearly as Out of Service, and send for repair or bench evaluation. Knowing when to stop prevents unnecessary downtime and protects patient safety. Escalation after logical checks is proper troubleshooting.

CCR.Cause: Unit does not power on with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. Rear switch verified ON. No indicator lights, fan noise, or display activity observed. Suspected internal power supply failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and tagged Out of Service. Sent to Biomed shop for bench evaluation. Dispatched for vendor repair.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: GE Carescape B650 – PDM Not Recognized
description: Structured Clinical Engineering troubleshooting guide for B650 patient monitor PDM recognition issues.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Never troubleshoot a PDM recognition issue while a patient is actively being monitored. Transfer the patient to a functioning monitor first. Always power down the monitor before removing or installing modules to prevent connector damage.

steps.title: Verify Proper Module Orientation and Full Seating
steps.instructions: Remove and reinsert the PDM, ensuring correct orientation. Confirm the module clicks or locks fully into position. The B650 requires full electrical contact between the PDM connector pins and the monitor slot.

steps.title: Inspect Connector Pins and Slot Condition
steps.instructions: Remove the PDM and inspect the connector area for bent pins, damage, or contamination. Inspect the monitor slot for debris or foreign material. Use compressed air if necessary. Do not use liquids. Even minor debris can interrupt communication between the PDM and monitor.

steps.title: Swap with a Known-Good PDM
steps.instructions: Install a PDM known to be functional. If the known-good PDM is recognized, the original PDM is likely faulty. If the known-good PDM is not recognized, suspect the monitor slot or internal interface.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Monitor
steps.instructions: Shut down the B650 completely. Remove AC power and allow the unit to fully discharge for 10–15 seconds. Restore power and reinsert the PDM after boot-up. This forces reinitialization of module communication.

steps.title: Check for Software/Firmware Compatibility
steps.instructions: Verify the monitor software revision supports the installed PDM. Review maintenance history for recent updates or configuration changes.

steps.title: Observe for Error Messages or LED Indicators
steps.instructions: Document any on-screen messages related to module detection. Note any abnormal boot behavior or repeated detection attempts.

CCR.Complaint: Monitor displays PDM not recognized when module is inserted.
CCR.Cause: Module not fully seated and/or faulty PDM identified after swap testing.
CCR.Resolution: Reseated module and cleaned slot; issue persisted. Verified failure with known-good PDM. Monitor removed from service and sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Monitor powered on and outlet verified
Final device disposition (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: GE Carescape B450 – PDM Not Recognized
description: Structured Clinical Engineering guide for situations where a B450 monitor fails to recognize its Patient Data Module (PDM).

steps.title: Check Module Orientation and Seating
steps.instructions: Ensure the PDM is correctly oriented and fully inserted into the monitor’s slot. A partially seated module can prevent recognition. Why it matters: The B450 requires full electrical contact with the PDM pins.

steps.title: Inspect Module and Slot for Debris
steps.instructions: Remove the PDM and visually inspect both the module connector and monitor slot. Clean gently with compressed air if needed—avoid liquids. Why it matters: Dust, lint, or foreign material can block proper electrical connection.

steps.title: Try a Known-Good PDM
steps.instructions: Swap in a PDM confirmed to be functional. If recognized, the original PDM may be faulty.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Monitor
steps.instructions: Turn off the B450, wait 10–15 seconds, and turn it back on. Reinsert the PDM after power-up. Why it matters: Some modules require a fresh initialization to be recognized.

steps.title: Check Firmware Version
steps.instructions: Confirm the monitor firmware supports the installed PDM. Consult the monitor’s maintenance records to ensure compatibility.

steps.title: Inspect for Indicator Lights / Error Messages
steps.instructions: Observe any blinking lights on the module or monitor. Note specific error codes for documentation and potential escalation.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: All external and easily verifiable causes have been ruled out. The PDM or monitor slot may be internally faulty. Action: Remove the monitor from service, label 'Out of Service,' send the monitor and/or PDM for bench evaluation or repair. Note: Knowing when to stop is proper troubleshooting.

CCR.Complaint: Monitor reports PDM not recognized when inserted.
CCR.Cause: PDM not fully seated and/or module contacts obstructed by lint.
CCR.Resolution: Cleaned module and slot, reinserted PDM, monitor recognized module; if issue persisted, device labeled Out of Service for repair.

helpfulDetails: Outlet tested and monitor powered correctly.
PDM swapped with a known-good module.
Any error messages or lights observed.
Final device status (recognized or sent for repair).

title: GE Carescape B450 – Touchscreen Not Responding
description: Structured Clinical Engineering guide for a GE Healthcare B450 patient monitor with an unresponsive touchscreen.

steps.title: Verify Power and Connections
steps.instructions: Ensure the monitor is properly plugged into a working outlet. Confirm the AC adapter or battery is seated correctly and operational. Why: Touchscreen may appear unresponsive if the device is underpowered.

steps.title: Check for Obstructions
steps.instructions: Clean the touchscreen with a soft, lint-free cloth and approved cleaner. Remove any screen protectors or films that may interfere. Why: Dirt, smudges, or residue can prevent proper touch recognition.

steps.title: Restart the Monitor
steps.instructions: Power cycle the device: turn it off, wait 30 seconds, then turn it back on. Why: Temporary software or firmware glitches can cause touchscreen freezes.

steps.title: Verify Input Method
steps.instructions: Ensure you are using a bare finger or approved stylus; other objects may not register. Why: The B450 touchscreen is capacitive and may not respond to non-approved objects.

steps.title: Check Display and Calibration Settings
steps.instructions: Navigate (if possible via physical buttons) to touchscreen calibration settings and re-calibrate. Why: Miscalibration can make the touchscreen appear unresponsive or inaccurate.

steps.title: Environmental Check
steps.instructions: Confirm the monitor is not exposed to excessive heat, moisture, or magnetic interference. Why: Environmental conditions can affect touchscreen sensitivity.

steps.title: Test with External Interface (if available)
steps.instructions: If the monitor supports external input (mouse or keyboard), test responsiveness. Why: Determines if the issue is software-related or strictly touchscreen hardware.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: Common external causes have been ruled out; the touchscreen or internal display controller may be failing. Remove monitor from service. Label “Out of Service.” Send to Biomedical Engineering or vendor repair. Note: Knowing when to escalate is proper troubleshooting.

CCR.Complaint: Touchscreen not responding during routine patient monitoring.
CCR.Cause: Monitor touchscreen remained unresponsive after confirming power, cleaning, and restarting the device.
CCR.Resolution: Monitor removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent for vendor evaluation.

title: GE Healthcare MAC VU360 – Leads Not Detected / Noisy ECG
description: Structured ECG troubleshooting for lead-off messages and noisy waveform conditions.

steps.title: Check Electrode Placement and Skin Prep
steps.instructions: Ensure electrodes are positioned according to standard ECG guidelines. Confirm the patient’s skin is clean, dry, and free of oils or lotion. If necessary, gently prep the skin to improve adhesion. Replace any dried, expired, or loose electrodes.

steps.title: Inspect Lead Wires and Connections
steps.instructions: Verify each lead wire is firmly snapped onto the electrode. Check for loose, bent, or damaged connectors. Inspect the patient cable for cracks, exposed wires, or signs of strain. Confirm the trunk cable is securely connected to the device.

steps.title: Reduce Electrical Interference
steps.instructions: Route ECG cables away from power cords and other electrical equipment. Ensure the patient is not touching metal surfaces. Minimize cable looping or tangling.

steps.title: Confirm Proper Lead Selection
steps.instructions: Verify the correct lead set configuration (3-lead, 5-lead, or 10-lead). Ensure the selected mode matches the cable type in use.

steps.title: Test with Known-Good Cable
steps.instructions: Swap the patient cable with a verified, known-good cable if available. Reconnect electrodes and reassess waveform quality.

steps.title: Perform Simulator Test
steps.instructions: Connect an ECG simulator and run a standard rhythm simulation. If the waveform is stable and clear, the issue is likely external (electrodes or cable). If the simulator tracing remains noisy or leads are not detected, suspect an internal problem.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: If leads remain undetected or the ECG remains noisy after completing the above steps, the issue may involve the patient cable assembly or internal acquisition board. Remove the unit from service. Label as Out of Service. Send for further diagnostic evaluation. Knowing when to stop is an essential part of proper troubleshooting.

CCR.Complaint: Example: “Multiple leads not detected and ECG waveform very noisy.”
CCR.Cause: Example: “Loose/dried electrodes and intermittent patient cable connection causing lead-off detection and artifact.”
CCR.Resolution: “Replaced electrodes and secured cable connections. Tested with simulator — unit operating normally.” “Failed simulator test. Removed from service for further evaluation.”

title: GE Carescape B450 – Won’t Power On / Random Shutdowns
description: Structured Clinical Engineering guide for a GE Healthcare B450 patient monitor that fails to power on or experiences random shutdowns.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Confirm the outlet is live using a known-working device. If connected via a power strip or extension cord, plug the monitor directly into the wall outlet. Why: Many power issues are caused by outlets or strips not supplying consistent voltage.

steps.title: Check Power Cord and Connections
steps.instructions: Inspect the power cord for cuts, fraying, or bent prongs. Ensure the cord is fully seated in both the monitor and the wall outlet. Why: Loose or damaged cords are a common cause of power failures and intermittent shutdowns.

steps.title: Inspect Battery and Charging
steps.instructions: Confirm the monitor battery is installed correctly and seated properly. If the battery is removable, check for swelling, leakage, or corrosion. Try powering the monitor with AC only (battery removed) to isolate battery vs. AC issues. Why: A failing battery can prevent startup or cause random shutdowns even when AC power is applied.

steps.title: Observe Power Indicators
steps.instructions: Note LED behavior when attempting to power on: steady, blinking, or no light. Compare with monitor documentation to interpret indicator patterns. Why: LED status can indicate battery issues, AC failure, or internal faults.

steps.title: Attempt Soft Reset (If Supported)
steps.instructions: Some B450 units have a reset procedure—usually holding the power button for a set duration. Only perform this if safe and per manufacturer guidance. Why: Temporary software glitches can sometimes prevent proper startup.

steps.title: Check Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Ensure monitor is not exposed to extreme temperatures, moisture, or liquids. Confirm ventilation is clear—overheating can cause shutdowns.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: After completing the above, if the monitor still won’t power on or shuts down randomly: Remove the monitor from service. Label it Out of Service. Send it for vendor repair or bench evaluation. Why: Continuing to troubleshoot internally without proper tools or schematics risks patient safety and further damage.

steps.title: Clinical Use Tip
steps.instructions: Never troubleshoot a monitor while it is connected to a patient. If a patient requires monitoring, move them to another verified working monitor first. Only perform troubleshooting in a safe, non-patient environment.

steps.title: Work Order Documentation (CCR Method)
steps.instructions: Complaint: “Monitor will not power on / randomly shuts down during use.” Cause: “Power cord inspected and seated properly. Battery removed and tested separately; LED indicator remains off. AC outlet verified as live. Environmental conditions normal. Issue persists.” Resolution: “Monitor removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent for vendor repair. Patient transferred to another monitor.”

steps.title: Helpful Details to Include
steps.instructions: Outlet tested with multimeter or known device. Power cord swapped or inspected. Battery removed/tested. LED behavior recorded. Monitor environment checked for temperature, moisture, and ventilation. Final status: Out of Service.

CCR.Complaint: Monitor will not power on / randomly shuts down during use.
CCR.Cause: Power cord inspected and seated properly. Battery removed and tested separately; LED indicator remains off. AC outlet verified as live. Environmental conditions normal. Issue persists.
CCR.Resolution: Monitor removed from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent for vendor repair. Patient transferred to another monitor.

helpfulDetails: Outlet tested with multimeter or known device
Monitor environment checked for temperature, moisture, and ventilation

title: GE MAC VU360 – Printer Issue – Not Printing / Poor Print Quality
description: Structured troubleshooting for a GE MAC VU360 ECG machine experiencing printer failures or poor print quality.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: If the device is actively being used for patient testing, complete or transfer the study to another ECG machine before troubleshooting. Do not disassemble or manipulate the printer while connected to a patient.

steps.title: Confirm Printer Is Enabled
steps.instructions: Access the system menu and verify the internal printer function is enabled. If disabled, enable the printer and initiate a controlled print test. This rules out configuration-related causes.

steps.title: Verify Paper Type and Installation
steps.instructions: Open the printer compartment and confirm: Correct thermal ECG paper is installed. Paper is loaded in the proper orientation. Paper is not curled, faded, or contaminated. Thermal printers require proper paper orientation; incorrect loading will result in blank output.

steps.title: Inspect Paper Path and Compartment
steps.instructions: Check for: Torn paper fragments. Dust buildup. Obstructions in the paper feed path. Gently clean with a dry lint-free cloth or compressed air. Do not use liquid cleaners on the thermal head.

steps.title: Check Print Density / Contrast Settings
steps.instructions: Navigate to print settings and verify density is set to default or appropriate levels. If output is faint, increase density slightly and re-test. Reset to default if necessary to rule out user adjustment.

steps.title: Perform Printer Self-Test
steps.instructions: Access the internal printer self-test through the system menu. Observe: Does paper feed properly? Is the test pattern clear and complete? Is output blank despite correct paper? If the self-test fails or prints poorly, this indicates likely internal printer or thermal head failure.

steps.title: Check for System Error Messages
steps.instructions: Review the display for printer-related error codes. Document exact wording of the message. Do not attempt board-level repair based on codes; this is for documentation and escalation.

CCR.Complaint: “ECG prints blank pages.” or “Printout is very faint and unreadable.”
CCR.Cause: “Printer enabled and correct thermal paper loaded. Density adjusted with no improvement. Printer self-test prints blank output. Suspected thermal print head failure.”
CCR.Resolution: “Removed unit from service and sent for repair.” or “Printer assembly replaced on bench. Self-test passed. Returned to service.”

helpfulDetails: Final device status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: GE CARESCAPE B850 – Will Not Turn On
description: Basic power troubleshooting for a GE CARESCAPE B850 patient monitor.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: If the monitor is in clinical use: transfer the patient to a functioning monitor first. Do not troubleshoot while the monitor is actively required for patient care. Confirm the device is safe to remove from service before proceeding.

steps.title: Verify AC Power at the Outlet
steps.instructions: Confirm the monitor is connected to a known-working hospital-grade outlet. Test the outlet with a known-good device (lamp, outlet tester, etc.). If plugged into a power strip, isolation transformer, or UPS, verify that device is powered on and functioning. If available, try a different known-working wall outlet. Why this matters: Loss of upstream power is the most common and simplest cause of a “dead” monitor.

steps.title: Inspect and Reseat the Power Cord
steps.instructions: Visually inspect the power cord for cuts, fraying, bent or damaged prongs, and loose connector ends. Reseat the cord firmly at the wall outlet and the rear AC inlet of the monitor. If available, swap with a known-good hospital-grade power cord and attempt to power on again. Why this matters: A loose or internally failed cord can mimic total device failure.

steps.title: Confirm the Rear Power Switch Position
steps.instructions: Verify the rear power rocker switch is in the ON position. Then press the front power button. Do not assume the switch position without physically checking it.

steps.title: Observe for Any Signs of Activity
steps.instructions: When attempting to power on, closely observe front LED indicators, brief screen flash, audible fan noise, or clicking sounds. Even minimal activity suggests partial power presence and helps narrow down whether the failure is complete or localized.

steps.title: If the Problem Persists
steps.instructions: If the monitor shows no indicator lights, no fan noise, no display activity, and no response with known-good outlet and power cord, then common external causes have been ruled out. At this point, the issue is likely internal (power supply board, internal fuse, or power distribution failure). Remove the monitor from service, label clearly as Out of Service, and send for repair or bench evaluation. Knowing when to stop prevents unnecessary downtime and protects patient safety. Escalation after logical checks is proper troubleshooting.

CCR.Cause: Unit does not power on with known-working outlet and known-good power cord. Rear switch verified ON. No indicator lights, fan noise, or display activity observed. Suspected internal power supply failure.
CCR.Resolution: Removed from service and tagged Out of Service. Sent to Biomed shop for bench evaluation. Dispatched for vendor repair.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (returned to service or sent for repair)

title: GE Carescape R860 Ventilator - Fails Pre-Use Check / Self-Test
description: Guide for troubleshooting pre-use check or self-test failures on GE Carescape R860 ventilators, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Ensure the ventilator is connected to a verified working outlet or fully charged battery. Why: Low or unstable power can prevent a successful self-test.

steps.title: Check Battery / Backup
steps.instructions: If on battery, ensure it is fully charged. Swap with a known good battery if available. Why: A weak battery can cause pre-use check failures.

steps.title: Inspect External Connections
steps.instructions: Confirm that all patient circuits, filters, humidifiers, and sensors are properly connected and seated. Why: Loose or missing components often trigger self-test errors.

steps.title: Check Oxygen Supply
steps.instructions: Ensure oxygen supply is on and within pressure range specified in the user guide. Why: Low or absent oxygen flow can cause self-test failure.

steps.title: Verify Circuit and Tubing Integrity
steps.instructions: Examine inspiratory and expiratory circuits for leaks, kinks, or disconnections. Why: The ventilator tests for leaks during self-test; leaks cause failure.

steps.title: Check Filters and Humidifiers
steps.instructions: Inspect and replace if clogged, wet, or incorrectly installed. Why: Obstructions affect pressure readings and self-test results.

steps.title: Perform a Restart
steps.instructions: Power cycle the ventilator after all external checks. Why: Reset can clear transient faults affecting the pre-use check.

steps.title: Review Error Messages
steps.instructions: Note any specific codes displayed during the failed self-test. Reference manufacturer troubleshooting charts. Why: Some error codes may indicate replaceable external components rather than internal failure.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator fails pre-use check / self-test, displays error code 102.
CCR.Cause: Observed loose expiratory circuit connection and wet filter.
CCR.Resolution: Reconnected circuit, replaced wet filter, power cycled ventilator, verified successful self-test.

helpfulDetails: Final status: Passes pre-use check after correction, ready for patient use.

title: GE Healthcare Aisys Anesthesia Machine – Fails System Checkout
description: Troubleshooting guide for GE Healthcare Aisys anesthesia machines that fail automated system checkout during startup.

steps.title: Ensure the Machine Is Not Connected to a Patient
steps.instructions: Never troubleshoot system checkout failures while connected to an active patient. Move the patient to an alternate anesthesia machine before proceeding. This protects patient safety and allows a full test cycle without interruption.

steps.title: Verify Proper Circuit Setup
steps.instructions: The Aisys performs a leak and compliance test during checkout. Check that a full breathing circuit is installed, inspiratory and expiratory limbs are connected securely, the Y-piece is capped during the leak test, the reservoir bag is installed properly, and the APL valve is appropriately adjusted per test instructions. A missing cap or loose fitting is one of the most common causes of checkout failure.

steps.title: Inspect for Obvious Leaks
steps.instructions: Visually and manually inspect CO₂ absorber canister seating, water trap installation, circuit connections at the absorber block, bag arm and manual ventilation port, and sample line connections. Listen for hissing sounds during the pressure phase of the test. If the pressure will not hold during checkout, a leak is likely present.

steps.title: Check Vaporizers
steps.instructions: Improperly seated vaporizers frequently cause checkout failure. Verify that vaporizers are fully locked into position, only one vaporizer is turned ON, filler caps are secure, and there is no visible damage to mounting seals. If unsure, turn vaporizers OFF and repeat checkout.

steps.title: Confirm Gas Supply
steps.instructions: Ensure O₂, Air, and N₂O pipeline pressures are within normal range, backup E-cylinders are either properly opened or confirmed full, and no gas supply alarms are active. Low or missing pipeline pressure can cause checkout failure.

steps.title: Drain Water Traps
steps.instructions: Excess moisture in flow or pressure sensing lines can affect system testing. Check and empty water traps, ensure sample lines are dry, and replace sample line if occluded. Moisture can cause sensor-related test failures.

steps.title: Reboot and Repeat System Checkout
steps.instructions: Power cycle the unit fully. Turn off the machine, wait 30–60 seconds, restart, and perform full system checkout again. Transient software faults can occasionally cause false failures.

steps.title: Note Specific Error Message
steps.instructions: Document the exact checkout failure message such as Leak test failed, Flow sensor failure, Pressure sensor failure, Ventilator test failure, or Gas module failure. The exact failure helps determine whether the issue is external or internal.

CCR.Complaint: OR staff reported the Aisys anesthesia machine failed system checkout with a ‘Leak Test Failed’ message at startup.
CCR.Cause: Found loose CO₂ absorber canister and Y-piece not capped during automated leak test. Machine unable to maintain test pressure.
CCR.Resolution: Reseated absorber canister, capped Y-piece, repeated system checkout. Machine passed full checkout and returned to service. Verified no alarms present.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (Returned to service or Sent for repair)

title: GE Healthcare Aisys Anesthesia Machine – Ventilator Not Delivering Set Volume
description: Troubleshooting guide for GE Healthcare Aisys anesthesia machine ventilator not delivering the set tidal volume, focusing on circuit integrity, gas supply, settings, and external causes before internal failure.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Immediately ensure the patient is being ventilated. If volume delivery is questionable, switch to manual bag ventilation using 100% O₂. Verify chest rise and adequate airway pressures. This ensures patient oxygenation while troubleshooting.

steps.title: Verify Ventilation Mode and Settings
steps.instructions: Confirm correct mode (e.g., Volume Control vs Pressure Control). Verify tidal volume setting is appropriate. Confirm respiratory rate and inspiratory time are correctly programmed. Incorrect mode or settings can mimic delivery failure.

steps.title: Check Fresh Gas Flow and Gas Supply
steps.instructions: Confirm pipeline pressures are within normal range (O₂, Air, N₂O as applicable). Ensure O₂ supply is not depleted if on cylinder backup. Verify no low supply pressure alarms are active. Insufficient gas supply can prevent full volume delivery.

steps.title: Inspect the Patient Circuit for Leaks
steps.instructions: Perform a manual leak check. Inspect: Circuit tubing connections, Y-piece, Elbow connectors, Humidifier connections, CO₂ absorber canister seating. Listen for audible leaks. Circuit leaks are one of the most common causes of low delivered volume.

steps.title: Check the Adjustable Pressure Limiting (APL) Valve (if in Manual Mode)
steps.instructions: Ensure APL valve is appropriately set and not fully open during manual ventilation. An open APL can vent volume before reaching the patient.

steps.title: Inspect the CO₂ Absorber and Breathing System
steps.instructions: Confirm absorber canister is fully seated and locked. Check for cracked housing or poor seal. Ensure unidirectional valves are not visibly stuck (without disassembly). Poor sealing in the breathing system can reduce effective delivered volume.

steps.title: Verify Airway Integrity
steps.instructions: Confirm endotracheal tube cuff inflation. Check for audible leak at the patient airway. Suction if obstruction suspected. A cuff leak or partial obstruction can alter delivered and measured volume.

steps.title: Perform System Leak / Compliance Test (if patient safely off circuit)
steps.instructions: Place the machine in standby. Perform automated system check. Observe compliance and leak test results. This helps determine whether the issue is internal to the ventilator or external to the circuit.

steps.title: Check Bellows or Piston Movement (Visual Observation Only)
steps.instructions: Confirm normal mechanical movement during inspiration and expiration. Observe for abnormal hesitation or incomplete stroke. Do not open internal compartments.

steps.title: Power Cycle if Appropriate
steps.instructions: Only if patient is safely supported on alternate ventilation. Restart system and allow self-test to complete. Software faults can occasionally affect delivery.

CCR.Complaint: OR staff reported anesthesia ventilator not delivering set tidal volume of 500 mL; exhaled volume reading approximately 250 mL with low volume alarm.
CCR.Cause: Found loose connection at CO₂ absorber canister causing circuit leak during positive pressure ventilation.
CCR.Resolution: Reseated and locked absorber canister. Performed leak test—passed. Verified delivered and exhaled volumes matched set tidal volume. Returned to service.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (Returned to Service or Sent for Repair)

title: GE Healthcare Aisys Anesthesia Machine Gas or Agent Delivery Errors
description: Troubleshooting gas and agent delivery errors on the GE Healthcare Aisys anesthesia machine, focusing on external checks before assuming internal failure.

steps.title: Ensure the Patient Is Safely Supported First
steps.instructions: If the issue occurs during a case, immediately transition the patient to manual ventilation or an alternate anesthesia machine. Do not continue troubleshooting while actively delivering anesthesia to a patient.

steps.title: Check Pipeline Gas Supply Pressures
steps.instructions: Verify wall supply pressures (O₂, Air, N₂O as applicable). Confirm hoses are securely connected and not kinked. Look for low-pressure pipeline alarms on the display. If pipeline pressure is low, connect a known-full E-cylinder and observe whether the alarm clears.

steps.title: Verify Cylinder Status (If Installed)
steps.instructions: Ensure cylinders are open and contain adequate pressure. Confirm no slow leaks at the yoke connections. Check that the cylinder is not cross-threaded or misaligned.

steps.title: Confirm Vaporizers Are Properly Seated and Locked
steps.instructions: Remove and reseat the vaporizer if needed. Ensure it is fully locked into position. Check that only one vaporizer is turned on (unless system allows otherwise). Verify adequate agent level in the vaporizer.

steps.title: Check Fresh Gas Flow Settings
steps.instructions: Confirm flow settings match clinical intent. Ensure O₂ flow is not set extremely low, which may prevent agent from reaching target concentration. Observe flow tubes or digital flow indicators for proper response when adjusting settings.

steps.title: Inspect the Breathing Circuit
steps.instructions: Perform a full leak test per hospital policy. Check for loose connections, cracked hoses, faulty CO₂ absorber canister seating, or improperly installed filters. Verify APL valve position during manual mode testing.

steps.title: Run the System Self-Test (If Not in Active Case)
steps.instructions: Power cycle the machine (only when patient is off the unit). Perform a full checkout test. Note any flow sensor, pressure sensor, or internal module errors. Document exact error codes for repair reference.

steps.title: Check for Recent Service or Configuration Changes
steps.instructions: Verify that recent PM, gas module replacement, or software updates did not precede the issue. Ensure calibration procedures were completed properly if recently serviced.

steps.title: Observe for Physical Signs
steps.instructions: Listen for unusual noises from internal gas modules. Smell for anesthetic agent inside machine housing. Check for inconsistent digital flow readings compared to external analyzer.

CCR.Complaint: OR staff reported the Aisys would not reach set Sevoflurane concentration and displayed low agent delivery alarm during induction.
CCR.Cause: Pipeline O₂ pressure was found below normal range due to loose wall hose connection. Machine operating normally once pressure restored.
CCR.Resolution: Re-secured pipeline hose connection, verified proper supply pressure, completed system checkout test, returned unit to service.

title: GE Avance Anesthesia Machine Ventilator Alarms / Poor Ventilation
description: Guide for troubleshooting ventilator alarms and poor ventilation in GE Avance anesthesia machines, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Patient Circuit Connections
steps.instructions: Check that all tubing, Y-piece, and patient connectors are securely attached. Ensure no kinks, twists, or disconnections exist.

steps.title: Inspect the Breathing Circuit and Filters
steps.instructions: Look for wet or clogged HME filters, CO₂ absorbent, or bacterial filters. Replace if saturated or visibly obstructed.

steps.title: Check Endotracheal Tube (ETT) Placement
steps.instructions: Confirm that the ETT is correctly positioned and not blocked. Suction secretions if needed.

steps.title: Assess Ventilator Settings and Mode
steps.instructions: Confirm tidal volume, rate, inspiratory time, and pressure limits are appropriate for patient size and mode. Reset to standard adult or pediatric parameters if needed.

steps.title: Verify Power and Gas Supply
steps.instructions: Check oxygen, air, and nitrous supply pressures. Ensure backup battery is charged if operating on battery power.

steps.title: Perform Visual and Audible Alarm Checks
steps.instructions: Look for any warning indicators on the screen. Listen for unexpected hissing or leaks.

steps.title: Conduct a Leak Test (Machine Only)
steps.instructions: With the patient disconnected, perform a machine leak test following standard external procedures.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator alarmed and patient tidal volumes are low during case.
CCR.Cause: High airway pressures noted; circuit tubing kinked and HME filter partially saturated.
CCR.Resolution: Straightened tubing and replaced filter; ventilator function returned to normal. Device tested and returned to service.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (operational, removed, or sent for repair)

title: GE Healthcare Avance Anesthesia Machine – Low Agent / Gas Delivery Alarms
description: Guide to troubleshoot low agent or gas delivery alarms on GE Avance anesthesia machines with a focus on external checks and patient safety.

steps.title: Check the Gas Supply Connections
steps.instructions: Verify that oxygen, nitrous oxide, and air supply lines are properly connected to the machine and fully open. Ensure pressure gauges read within normal ranges. Why: Low or disconnected supply lines can trigger delivery alarms immediately.

steps.title: Inspect the Vaporizers
steps.instructions: Confirm that vaporizers are correctly seated and locked in place. Check that the anesthetic agent levels are adequate. Look for any leaks around the vaporizer ports. Why: Improperly seated vaporizers or low agent can cause low delivery alarms.

steps.title: Verify Circuit Connections
steps.instructions: Ensure the patient circuit is properly connected and free of kinks or occlusions. Check the CO₂ absorber and breathing bag for proper installation. Why: Leaks or disconnections in the circuit can cause false low delivery alarms.

steps.title: Examine Flow Settings and Monitoring
steps.instructions: Confirm that flowmeters are set correctly and functional. Ensure the machine is not in a mode that limits agent delivery (e.g., standby). Why: Misconfigured flows can mimic delivery problems even when gas supply is adequate.

steps.title: Check Alarms and Sensors
steps.instructions: Inspect oxygen and agent concentration sensors for proper connection and cleanliness. Reset alarms and observe if they recur. Why: Faulty sensors may trigger alarms without an actual delivery issue.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Machine
steps.instructions: Safely power down, wait 30 seconds, and power back on. Observe self-test results and verify if alarms persist. Why: Software glitches or transient errors can sometimes cause false alarms.

CCR.Complaint: Low agent delivery alarm triggered during case; insufficient anesthetic observed.
CCR.Cause: Vaporizer improperly seated; agent level low; patient circuit connections verified and flowmeters functional.
CCR.Resolution: Reseated vaporizer, refilled agent, verified all connections; alarms cleared; machine returned to service after self-test.

title: GE Healthcare Avance Anesthesia Machine - Won’t Boot / Locks During Startup
description: Guide to troubleshoot GE Avance anesthesia machine failing to boot or locking during startup, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Power Source
steps.instructions: Ensure the power cord is securely connected to the machine and wall outlet. Confirm the outlet has proper voltage using a meter or a known-working device. Check any inline power switches or circuit breakers. Why: Insufficient or intermittent power can prevent proper booting.

steps.title: Inspect the Power Cord and Connector
steps.instructions: Look for frayed cords, bent pins, or loose connections. Replace the cord if any damage is found. Why: A faulty cord can cause startup failures or intermittent locking.

steps.title: Check Battery and Backup Power (if applicable)
steps.instructions: If the machine has a battery module, ensure it is installed correctly and charged. Remove the battery and attempt startup on AC power only. Why: A failing battery can interfere with booting or cause freezing.

steps.title: Environmental and Setup Factors
steps.instructions: Verify ambient temperature is within manufacturer-specified limits. Ensure no peripheral modules or patient circuits are attached in a way that could prevent startup. Why: Extreme temperatures or certain hardware conflicts may block boot.

steps.title: Perform a Safe Power Cycle
steps.instructions: Disconnect AC power and battery (if applicable) for 1–2 minutes. Reconnect and power on the machine. Observe any messages or self-test results. Why: Power cycling clears transient faults or software hangs.

steps.title: Observe Startup Behavior
steps.instructions: Note any error codes or messages displayed on the screen. Document which stage the machine locks or fails. Why: This information is critical for vendor service escalation.

CCR.Complaint: Machine will not boot; locks during startup, unable to perform self-test.
CCR.Cause: AC power verified; cord intact; battery removed and reinstalled; power cycle attempted; startup still fails.
CCR.Resolution: Machine removed from service, labeled Out of Service, escalated to vendor for bench evaluation.

helpfulDetails: AC outlet verified and voltage documented
Battery presence and charge status noted

title: GE Carestation 600 Series Touchscreen / Software Issues
description: Guide to troubleshoot touchscreen and software issues on the GE Carestation 600 anesthesia machine.

steps.title: Verify Power and Battery Backup
steps.instructions: Ensure the machine is plugged into a properly functioning outlet. Test the outlet if necessary. Check the UPS or battery backup (if applicable) for sufficient charge. Why: Touchscreen and software errors can be caused by unstable power.

steps.title: Inspect Cables and Connections
steps.instructions: Confirm all external cables (power, network, USB devices) are firmly seated. Remove any recently added peripherals that could interfere with the touchscreen. Why: Loose connections can cause system freezes or touchscreen errors.

steps.title: Perform a Soft Reboot
steps.instructions: Use the machine’s standard restart procedure (via the touchscreen menu or power button). Wait for the system to fully reboot and check touchscreen response. Why: Temporary software glitches are often resolved with a controlled reboot.

steps.title: Check for System Alerts or Error Messages
steps.instructions: Review the error logs or alerts displayed on the monitor. Record any recurring messages for documentation. Why: Persistent errors may indicate a software or module problem.

steps.title: Test Touchscreen Responsiveness
steps.instructions: Perform simple touch tests across the display to identify unresponsive areas. Note if the problem is localized (single area) or affects the entire screen. Why: This can distinguish between calibration issues, software, or hardware faults.

steps.title: Run Self-Diagnostics (if available)
steps.instructions: Access the machine’s diagnostic menu and run any touchscreen or software checks. Follow on-screen recommendations for minor software resets or calibrations. Why: Self-diagnostics can confirm whether the issue is software or touchscreen hardware.

steps.title: Review Recent Updates or Configuration Changes
steps.instructions: Determine if any software updates, patches, or configuration changes were applied recently. Roll back changes if feasible to test system stability. Why: Software errors often coincide with recent updates.

CCR.Complaint: Touchscreen unresponsive and software freezes intermittently during cases.
CCR.Cause: No loose cables, power stable, soft reboot and diagnostics performed; issue persists.
CCR.Resolution: Machine removed from service, labeled Out of Service, GE Healthcare service scheduled.

helpfulDetails: Any recent software updates or configuration changes

title: GE Carestation 600 Series Fails Pre-Use Checkout
description: Guide for troubleshooting the GE Carestation 600 Series anesthesia machine when pre-use checkout fails.

steps.title: Ensure Machine is Properly Powered
steps.instructions: Confirm the machine is connected to a verified hospital power outlet. Check that circuit breakers are on and that the machine shows normal startup sequence. Why: Pre-use checkout may fail if the machine is underpowered or voltage fluctuates.

steps.title: Check Gas Supply Lines
steps.instructions: Confirm oxygen, nitrous oxide, and air cylinders or pipeline connections are secure. Verify adequate pressure at each supply source. Why: Low or disconnected gas supply can trigger checkout failures.

steps.title: Inspect Breathing Circuit and Consumables
steps.instructions: Check for leaks, loose connections, or damaged breathing circuits, hoses, and reservoirs. Ensure CO₂ absorber is correctly seated and not expired. Confirm ventilator circuit is fully assembled. Why: Leak detection is a common reason for pre-use checkout failure.

steps.title: Verify Sensors and Monitors
steps.instructions: Confirm all patient monitoring cables, flow sensors, and O₂ sensors are properly connected. Check for sensor damage or obstruction. Why: Checkout will fail if vital sensors are missing, disconnected, or malfunctioning.

steps.title: Run Self-Test After Reset
steps.instructions: Power cycle the machine. Perform a manual reset or initialize the self-test routine per standard protocol. Why: Temporary software glitches or incomplete boot sequences can cause false failures.

steps.title: Check Alarms and Error Messages
steps.instructions: Note any error codes displayed. Consult the machine’s quick reference guide for specific external troubleshooting recommendations. Why: Some codes indicate simple fixes (e.g., blocked scavenger line, sensor misalignment).

CCR.Complaint: Pre-use checkout fails with leak and sensor errors.
CCR.Cause: Observed loose O₂ sensor and a misaligned breathing circuit during troubleshooting.
CCR.Resolution: Re-seated sensor and circuit connections; retested self-check. If failure persists, machine labeled Out of Service for repair.

helpfulDetails: Final machine status before removing from service

title: GE Carestation 600 Series Oxygen / Gas Supply Alarms Guide
description: Troubleshooting guide for oxygen and gas supply alarms on the GE Carestation 600 Series anesthesia machine, focusing on external verifiable causes first.

steps.title: Verify Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Ensure the patient is on an alternate oxygen source or ventilator if the machine is actively in use. Do not troubleshoot the gas supply while the patient is dependent on this machine.

steps.title: Check Cylinder Supply
steps.instructions: Ensure O₂, N₂O, and air cylinders are present, properly secured, and at adequate pressure. Verify cylinder regulators are open and functioning. Look for low-pressure or empty cylinder indications on the front panel.

steps.title: Check Pipeline Gas Connections
steps.instructions: Confirm pipeline hoses are properly connected to the wall outlets. Verify the correct gas is connected to each inlet (O₂, N₂O, Air). Inspect for kinks, leaks, or loose fittings in the supply hoses.

steps.title: Verify Pipeline Pressure
steps.instructions: Check the machine’s pressure gauges for O₂, Air, and N₂O. Normal pipeline pressures: O₂ ~50 psi, Air ~50 psi, N₂O ~50 psi (confirm with local hospital standards). If pressure is low, check with the central supply department; the pipeline may be offline.

steps.title: Check Flowmeters and Vaporizers
steps.instructions: Ensure vaporizers are seated correctly and the interlock system is engaged. Confirm that flow control knobs are functioning and not jammed.

steps.title: Inspect Alarm and System Messages
steps.instructions: Note the exact alarm message (e.g., “O₂ Low Pressure,” “Pipeline Fail,” “O₂ Supply Failure”). Some alarms may clear if the correct supply source is selected.

steps.title: Swap External Hoses or Cylinders if Available
steps.instructions: If you have a spare hose or cylinder, swap it to rule out external defects.

CCR.Complaint: O₂ supply alarm sounding during case, unable to maintain set O₂ concentration.
CCR.Cause: Pipeline O₂ pressure low; cylinder pressures adequate; no kinks in hoses; supply connections verified.
CCR.Resolution: Machine removed from service, labeled Out of Service, notified GE service for bench evaluation. Patient transferred to backup anesthesia machine.

helpfulDetails: Pipeline and cylinder pressures at time of alarm
Visual inspection of hoses, regulators, and fittings
Vaporizers in use and interlock status
